perturbation.explanation: Replacing the second date with '[ILLEGAL DATE]' introduces ambiguity and potential unenforceability to the contract, as the effective date is a critical element for establishing the agreement's validity. Contract law requires clear and definite terms, especially concerning dates and timelines. Using an undefined term like '[ILLEGAL DATE]' creates uncertainty and could lead to disputes regarding the contract's commencement and duration.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law Principles - Requirement of Definiteness

perturbation.original_text:
This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding
Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc.
(hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter
referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the
aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ
and ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies.
perturbation.changed_text:
This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding
Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc.
(hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter
referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the
aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall only apply to PCQ and exclude ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies.
perturbation.explanation: Limiting the amendment's application to only one party (PCQ) while excluding the other (ABW) creates a fundamental issue of mutuality and consideration. Contract law requires that both parties receive some benefit or incur some detriment for an agreement to be enforceable. This modification effectively creates a one-sided agreement, potentially voiding the entire amendment due to lack of reciprocal obligation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law Principles - Requirement of Mutuality/Consideration

perturbation.original_text:
This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding
Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc.
(hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter
referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the
aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ
and ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies.
perturbation.changed_text:
This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding
Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc.
(hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter
referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the
aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply retroactively to all subsidiaries and related companies before January 1, 1900.
perturbation.explanation: Applying the amendment retroactively to entities before 1900 is nonsensical and potentially unenforceable. It attempts to bind entities that may not have existed or had any relationship with the parties at that time. This introduces absurdity and conflicts with basic principles of contract formation and privity, which state that contracts generally bind only the parties who agree to them.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law Principles - Retroactivity and Privity of Contract
